Article Magnetically recyclable high-entropy metal oxide catalyst for aerobic catalytic oxidative desulfurization Peiwen Wu a b Chang Deng a Feng Liu c Haonan Zhu a Linlin Chen a Ruoyu Liu a Wenshuai Zhu a b * Chunming Xu b a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Jiangsu University Zhenjiang Jiangsu 212013 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, Jiangsu, China b College of Chemical Engineering and Environment, State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum-Beijing, Beijing 102249, China College of Chemical Engineering and Environment State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum-Beijing Beijing 102249 China College of Chemical Engineering and Environment, State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum-Beijing, Beijing 102249, China c SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing Co. Ltd, Beijing 100083, China SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing Co. Ltd Beijing 100083 China SINOPEC Research Institute of Petroleum Processing Co. Ltd, Beijing 100083, China * Corresponding author. High-entropy metal oxide catalysts have demonstrated exceptional performance in activating oxygen for catalytic oxidation reactions. However, ensuring their ease of cyclic usage is crucial to broadening their applications. To address this challenge, a magnetic and recyclable high-entropy metal oxide catalyst is designed and its potential in catalytic oxidative desulfurization of fuel oils with oxygen as the oxidant is also investigated. Through a mechanochemical-assisted calcination method, the magnetic high-entropy metal oxide catalyst (HEMO-900) is successfully synthesized, and the structure of the HEMO-900 catalyst is comprehensively characterized. In addition, it is found that the high-entropy structure facilitates charge modulation of the active components, thereby enhancing the oxygen activation performance. The HEMO-900 catalyst exhibits exceptional oxygen activation ability and catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance, and 96.9% of sulfur removal is achieved under optimal conditions. In addition, it achieves profound desulfurization of various fuel samples by efficiently oxidizing and eliminating diverse aromatic sulfur compounds. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrates outstanding magnetically recyclable properties, enabling rapid separation and recovery from the fuel oil phase through the application of an external magnetic field, making the HEMO-900 catalyst maintained a remarkable sulfur removal efficiency of 91.1% even in the 5th cycle. Therefore, this magnetically recyclable HEMO-900 catalyst possesses significantly promising research and application prospects in the field of catalytic oxidative desulfurization of fuel oils with oxygen as the oxidant, as well as some other heterogeneous catalysis. Graphical Abstract A magnetically recyclable high-entropy metal oxide catalyst was engineered via mechanochemical-assisted calcination method, and the catalyst exhibited excellent performance and magnetically recyclable property in oxidative desulfurization of fuel oils with oxygen as the oxidant. Keywords High entropy Transition metal oxide Magnetic separation Catalytic oxidation Desulfurization 1 Introduction In recent years, with the rapid development of the automotive industry, the environmental impact stemming from the combustion of sulfide compounds, leading to the emission of a substantial quantity of sulfur oxides (SO x ), has become a progressively escalating concern [1–7]. In response to this situation, various regions and nations across the globe have implemented stringent regulations to limit the sulfur in fuel oils [8]. For instance, countries such as China, European nations, and the United States have established regulations mandating that the sulfur content in gasoline and diesel fuels be maintained at levels below 10 parts per million (0.001%) [9–13]. Currently, hydrodesulfurization (HDS) has been regarded as the predominant industrial methodology utilized for the elimination of sulfide compounds from fuel oils [14–16]. However, HDS exhibits limited efficiency in removing aromatic sulfides, requiring higher hydrogen (H2) pressures, increased H2 consumption, and elevated reaction temperatures [17–23]. On the other hand, in the course of the HDS process, aromatic sulfides are regarded as pollutants and are converted into H2S [24,25]. Nevertheless, aromatic sulfides possess considerable value as high-value-added substances utilized in the synthesis of fine chemicals, including intermediate compounds employed in the manufacturing of semiconductors and pharmaceuticals. Thus, many non-HDS strategies have been developed to remove aromatic sulfides from fuel oils [26–28]. Among the various non-HDS techniques, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) stands out as a compelling alternative due to its notable advantages, such as its ability to effectively desulfurize aromatic sulfides, cost–effectiveness, and mild reaction conditions [29,30]. ODS is typically realized through the catalytic oxidation of aromatic sulfides into sulfones with the presence of a catalyst and an oxidant, resulting in compounds with polarity. Subsequently, the sulfone products can be conveniently separated using extraction or adsorption techniques. Furthermore, these obtained sulfones are high-added-value products, inducing the potential of ODS for valuable applications. In particular, ODS with oxygen (O2) as the oxidant has garnered significant attention due to the abundant reserves, cost–effectiveness, and environmental friendliness characteristics of oxygen [30–33]. Nevertheless, the inherent triplet ground state of oxygen requires the exploration and development of exceptionally active catalysts that are capable of effectively activating oxygen, which is of paramount significance in driving forward the progress and advancement of ODS technologies [34,35]. Metal oxides have demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance in ODS using oxygen as the oxidant [36,37]. The remarkable catalytic oxidation activity of metal oxides is primarily derived from their distinctive electronic structure, presence of oxygen vacancies, abundance of active surface sites, and various oxidation states. However, traditional metal oxides possess limited oxygen vacancies and active sites, making the metal oxides less active. High entropy metal oxides (HEMOs), which refer to solid solutions of metal oxides containing five or more metal elements, have garnered significant attention in the field of catalysis [38–47]. The formation of a high entropy structure in HEMOs leads to the emergence of several advantageous effects, including the high entropy effect, lattice distortion, and cocktail effect. These effects play a crucial role in the catalytic performance of HEMOs. The high entropy effect contributes to the tuning of electronic structures of catalytically active sites, while lattice distortion enhances the catalytic activity by introducing structural changes [48–50]. Additionally, the cocktail effect, resulting from the combination of multiple metal elements, promotes synergistic interactions and creates more vacancies, further enhancing the catalytic of HEMOs [51,52]. On the other hand, HEMOs struggle with challenges in terms of post-reaction separation. Drawing inspiration from recent advancements in magnetic catalysts and the cocktail effect of HEMOs, the introduction of magnetic elements to HEMOs holds promise for the development of a highly active catalyst with magnetic separation capabilities for ODS with oxygen as the oxidant. In this work, a high-temperature stable magnetic HEMO catalyst with both magnetic and catalytic activity was designed and synthesized. Leveraging the characteristic of high entropy materials, a magnetic high entropy metal oxide catalyst, CoCrFeMnNiO x (HEMO), was obtained using a mechanochemical-assisted calcination method. Since the free energy of the material is governed by the maximal configurational entropy rather than cohesive energy, the formation of the HEMO catalyst allows for uniform distribution of elements, and structural stability at elevated temperatures. The highly dispersed magnetic elements also confer excellent magnetic properties to the HEMO catalyst. Finally, ODS experiments were conducted on the prepared catalyst, revealing its promising ODS activity and deep desulfurization performance. Additionally, the influence of ball milling on the formation of high entropy structure was investigated, and it was found that ball milling of the precursor can effectively reduce the formation temperature of the high entropy structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O, A.R.), manganese chloride tetrahydrate (MnCl2·4H2O, A.R.), ferric trichloride (FeCl3, A.R.), chromium chloride hexahydrate (CrCl3·6H2O, A.R.), ethanol (A.R.), carbon tetrachloride (CCl4, A.R.), and acetone (A.R.) were obtained from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., LTD without further purification. Dodecane (99%), cetane (99%), nickel acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O, A.R.), dibenzothiophene (DBT, 98%), 4,6- dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT, 97%), 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT, 98%) were purchased from Merck Sigma-Aldrich. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst The detailed synthesis process is shown in Fig. 1 as the following process: Following Hume-Rothery's rule, a solid-solution phase can be formed when the atomic size difference between the constituent metal elements is less than 15%. Table S1 presents the atomic size differences for the selected metal species employed in this study, demonstrating that all the metal pairs exhibit atomic size differences that fall within the required range of less than 15%. Afterward, equimolar amounts of CoCl2·6H2O, MnCl2·4H2O, FeCl3, CrCl3·6H2O and Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O were mixed together to obtain a mixture. The mixture was physically blended using an agate mortar, followed by ball milling for a duration of 6 h. Subsequently, the milled precursor was transferred to a tube furnace for thermal treatment under the air atmosphere at temperatures of 800, 900, 1000, and 1100 °C, with a dwell time of 4 h (heating rate of 5 °C min−1). After naturally cooling to room temperature, magnetic high entropy metal oxide catalysts, namely HEMO-800, HEMO-900, HEMO-1000, and HEMO-1100, were obtained. The molar ratios of the metal elements remained constant in all samples. 2.3 Characterization The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern of the sample was recorded using an XRD-6100 instrument (Shimadzu, Japan). The morphology of the sample was examined using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-6010 PLUS/LA) equipped with a tungsten filament. The XRD measurement covered a 2θ range from 10° to 80°, with a scanning speed of 7°min−1. The elemental composition and oxidation states of the sample were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+). The magnetic hysteresis loop of the sample was measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (Lakeshore 7404). High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin operated at 300 kV. 2.4 Preparation of model oil and ODS process To replicate the ODS conditions in real oil, three commonly aromatic sulfur compounds, including DBT, 4,6-DMDBT, and 4-MDBT, were employed as the model sulfur substrates in diesel fuels. A model oil was prepared by dissolving a certain quantity of each sulfur compound in dodecane, with hexadecane serving as the internal standard for. The preparation involved the mixing of a predetermined amount of DBT with dodecane, followed by dilution with additional dodecane to achieve a volume of 1000 mL, resulting in a sulfur content of 0.02% in the model oil. The same procedure was repeated to prepare model oils with 0.02% of 4,6-DMDBT and 0.02% of 4-MDBT as the substrates, respectively. Notably, the DBT model oils were prepared with different sulfur contents of 0.02% and 0.03%. The ODS process with molecular oxygen as the oxidant was conducted in a 50 mL three-neck round-bottom flask. 20 mL of the model oil and 0.02 g of catalyst were added to the flask. The resulting mixture was subjected to stirring at a constant temperature using an oil bath, with a stirring speed of 1000 r min−1. Molecular oxygen was employed as the oxidant, and its flow rate was set at 150 mL min−1. Throughout the reaction, samples of the upper oil phase were collected every 30 minutes for subsequent analysis using a gas chromatograph (GC Agilent-7890A). The sulfur removal efficiency was determined by the following equation. Sulfur removal (%) = (Initial sulfur content (%) – Sulfur content after the reaction (%))/Initial sulfur content (%) × 100% 2.5 Recycling of the catalyst Following each ODS reaction, the catalyst was magnetically separated, and the oil was decanted. The entire sequence of these procedures is regarded as a single reaction cycle. The retrieved catalyst was subsequently employed for subsequent cycles, repeating the aforementioned steps until a noticeable decline in catalyst activity was observed. 2.6 Determination of ODS products After a specific number of reaction cycles, the catalyst is separated, and the reaction products adhering to the catalyst surface are extracted and isolated using CCl4 as the extractant. Subsequently, the extracted solution is subjected to analysis using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) to determine the ODS products present in the solvent. Moreover, the sulfur-containing compounds in the upper oil phase obtained from the ongoing reaction as well as the initial model oil were also examined via GC-MS to identify the types of sulfur-containing substrates. Furthermore, the collected reaction products, specifically the sulfones, were extracted and purified by following steps: With the existence of an externally magnetic field, the HEMO catalyst was magnetically separated, allowing for its efficient separation from the reaction mixture. Following separation, the residual oil on the catalyst was removed by a drying process. The catalyst phase was further subjected to a comprehensive washing procedure utilizing anhydrous ethanol as the washing solvent. Subsequently, the ethanol phase, containing the extracted oil residues, is effectively separated from the catalyst phase through magnetic separation. Finally, the ethanol phase is subjected to a drying process, leading to the isolation of the sulfone compounds that have accumulated on the catalyst surface. 3 Results and discussion The crystal structure analysis of the HEMO catalysts was performed using XRD technique, and the corresponding results are presented in Fig. 2 . In the XRD pattern of HEMO-900, distinct diffraction peaks were observed at 2θ degree of 18.4°, 30.3°, 35.7°, 43.5°, 57.5°, and 63.1°, which can be assigned to the lattice planes of (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) of the spinel-type oxide structure, respectively. These findings are consistent with the reference pattern provided in the standard PDF card (PDF#22-1084) for cobalt chromium spinel (CoCr2O4) (Fig. 2). The observed diffraction peaks exhibit high peak intensities, indicating the formation of a highly crystalline and predominantly pure spinel-type single-phase solid solution consisting of high-entropy metal oxides [53]. Furthermore, upon comparing the XRD analysis results of the samples synthesized at various calcination temperatures, it is evident that the precursor has already transformed into a fully formed and pure high-entropy spinel metal oxide structure when subjected to a calcination temperature of 800 °C. The successful incorporation of metal cations into the spinel structure is also confirmed by the XRD analysis. Firstly, by comparing HEMO-900 with standard single metal oxide patterns (Fig. S1), it is evident that the non-spinel oxides NiO (Fm-3m), MnO (Fm-3m), and Cr2O3 (R-3c) have been successfully incorporated into the spinel structure comprising Fe3O4(Fd-3m) and Co3O4 (Fd-3m). Additionally, when comparing the XRD pattern of the HEMO-900 with Co3O4 (PDF#80-1537), a noticeable shift towards smaller angles is observed. Complementing this finding, XPS analysis (Fig. 6 (a)) reveals the presence of Co2+ and Co3+ species in the sample. Based on the average atomic radius estimation formula, , the calculated average radius of Co ions is determined to be 0.57 Å, which is smaller than the average atomic radius of the other four elements in the doping system (0.60 Å). This observation indicates the successful doping of dopant atoms with larger radii, leading to an expansion of the unit cell parameters and interplanar spacing. To emphasize the effect of milling on the formation of HEMOs, the sample obtained at without pre-milling treatment was prepared. Upon comparison with the XRD characterization results in Fig. 3 , it is observed that in the non-milled sample, certain peaks correspond to impurity phases. Specifically, the peaks at 2θ = 24.2°, 33.2°, and 49.5° are attributed to the (012), (104), and (024) crystal planes of rhombohedral Fe2O3, while the peaks at 2θ = 23.2°, 32.9°, 38.3°, 45.2°, 49.4°, 55.2°, and 65.9° correspond to the (211), (222), (400), (332), (431), (440), and (622) crystal planes of cubic ABO3-type rare earth manganese iron oxide (FeMnO3). Typically, the formation of high-entropy metal materials requires annealing temperatures of 900 °C or above. However, the ball-milling process reduces the thermodynamic stability of the precursor and introduces dislocations and grain boundaries, thereby augmenting the internal energy and subsequently decreasing the formation temperature of the high-entropy structure [54]. Moreover, ball milling promotes the storage of enthalpy through severe plastic deformation, providing an additional mechanism for energy accumulation. The microstructure of the HEMO-900 catalyst was investigated using SEM. The SEM image of the prepared HEMO-900 catalyst, as shown in Figs. 4(a) and 4(b) , reveals the presence of numerous smooth particles with diameters ranging from approximately 200 to 900 nm in HEMO-900. However, some sintering and agglomeration between the particles can be observed, potentially attributed to prolonged high-temperature calcination. To further analyze the elemental distribution, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of the HEMO-900 of Fig. 4(c) was performed Figs. 4(d)–(h). The EDS mapping confirms a uniform distribution of Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, and Ni elements in the HEMO-900. This uniform distribution can be attributed to the unique characteristics of high-entropy materials, which prioritize maximum configurational entropy over cohesive energy [54]. Consequently, this behavior effectively prevents the sintering and agglomeration of metallic elements during high–temperature calcination, ensuring a highly dispersed distribution of elements within the HEMO-900 catalyst. To further investigate the microstructure and confirm the single crystal structure of HEMO-900, TEM and HRTEM characterization was performed in Fig. 5 . The observed microstructure in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b) reveal the presence of smooth particles with diameters ranging from approximately 200 to 900 nm, exhibiting some signs of high-temperature sintering. Such a result is consistent with the SEM characterization in Fig. 4. Notably, clear lattice fringes are visible in the HRTEM images (Figs. 5(c)–(f)), indicating a single crystal structure. In combination with the XRD results in Fig. 2, lattice spacing measurements of 0.29 nm (Fig. 5(d)) and 0.25 nm (Fig. 5(f)) were obtained from the HRTEM images, corresponding to the diffraction peaks at 30.4° and 35.8° in the XRD pattern, respectively. By comparing these lattice spacings with the standard PDF card, they can be attributed to the (220) and (311) crystal planes of the spinel structure (PDF#74-2081). This confirms the exceptional crystallinity and single-crystal structure of HEMO-900. Moreover, the dispersion of each element plays a crucial role in the formation of high-entropy structures. EDS mapping results, presented in Figs. 5(g)–(l), were conducted to assess the element dispersion within the HEMO. The results demonstrate a uniform dispersion of Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni, and O throughout the material, further indicating the successful formation of the high-entropy structure. The chemical environments of all the elements in HEMO-900 were characterized using XPS, and the results were presented in Figs. 6 and S2. The total XPS spectrum of HEMO-900 confirmed the presence of Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni, and O elements (Fig. S2), which is consistent with the EDS mapping results in Figs. 5(h)–(l). The Co 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 6(a) exhibits characteristic peaks at 779.9 and 795.4 eV (Fig. 6(a)), which correspond to the Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 states of Co(III). The peaks at 786.7 and 802.2 eV are assigned to satellite peaks for Co. Additionally, another group of peaks at 781.8 and 797.3 eV are observed, attributed to the Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 states of Co(II) [41]. This indicates the coexistence of Co(II) and Co(III) in the HEMO-900. In the Cr 2p XPS spectrum shown in Fig. 6(b), peaks at 576.1 and 585.4 eV are observed, corresponding to the Cr 2p 3/2 and Cr 2p 1/2 states of Cr(III) [55]. Furthermore, another group of peaks can be detected at 578.2 and 587.5 eV, being attributed to Cr 2p 3/2 and Cr 2p 1/2 states of Cr(VI), respectively. Such a result confirms the Cr in HEMO is present in the form of Cr(III) and Cr(VI). The Fe 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 6(c) exhibits peaks at 710.6 and 724.2 eV, attributed to the Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 states of Fe(II), along with peaks at 713.3 and 726.4 eV, corresponding to the Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 states of Fe(III). This suggests the coexistence of Fe(II) and Fe(III) in the HEMO-900 sample. Similarly, the Mn 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 6(d) displays peaks at 641.6 and 653.3 eV, attributed to the Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2 states of Mn(III), as well as peaks at 644.0 and 655.7 eV, corresponding to the Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2 states of Mn(IV). This indicates the coexistence of Mn(III) and Mn(IV) in the HEMO-900. In the Ni 2p XPS spectrum depicted in Fig. 6(e), peaks at 854.3 and 872.7 eV are observed, corresponding to the Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 states of Ni(II), while peaks at 855.5 and 873.3 eV are attributed to the Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 states of Ni(III). This suggests the coexistence of Ni(II) and Ni(III) in the sample. The O 1s spectrum presented in Fig. 6(f) exhibits a main peak and two shoulder peaks. Fitting analysis reveals three peaks at 529.7, 530.5, and 531.9 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (OL, M–O), oxygen vacancies (OV), and surface adsorbed oxygen species (Ow) in HEMO, respectively. XPS analysis reveals the coexistence of multiple valence states of metal elements in HEMO-900, offering advantageous implications for the activation of oxygen molecules. This characteristic facilitates the efficient catalytic oxidation and desulfurization of sulfide compounds. To gain deeper insights into the effect of forming a high-entropy structure on the charge distribution of the catalyst components, single metal oxide catalysts were synthesized using the same procedures as for HEMO-900. Subsequently, the charge structures of all the elements in these catalysts were analyzed using XPS in Figs. S3–S12. The results reveal that the synthesized single metal oxide catalysts also exhibited mixed valence states (Figs. S3–S7). However, compared with the XPS spectra of single metal oxides, in the XPS spectra of HEMO-900, distinct shifts of characteristic peaks corresponding to different valence states of each metal element towards higher binding energies were observed (Table S2), indicating the formation of a solid-solution phase of metal oxides. Moreover, comparing the peak area ratios of different valence states of the same element in single metal oxide catalysts and HEMO-900, a significant increase in the content of higher valence states of metal elements is demonstrated after the formation of the high-entropy structure, which favors a remarkable enhancement in catalytic oxidation activity. Further analysis focused on the O element in Figs. S8–S13 illustrates that all the obtained metal oxides contained Ov. However, the peak area ratio of Ov and lattice O (OL) in HEMO-900 was significantly higher than that in single metal oxide catalysts (Table S3). Such a result suggests that the formation of a high-entropy structure substantially increased the concentration of oxygen defects in metal oxides. This enhancement in oxygen defects contributes to improved activity towards oxygen activation, ultimately leading to enhanced ODS performance [55]. The catalytic oxidative desulfurization activities of the HEMO samples were investigated in Fig. 7 . The effect of formation temperature of the high-entropy structure catalytic activity was examined to determine the optimal synthesis temperature. The results are presented in Fig. 7(a), revealing the sulfur removals after 8 h of reaction for HEMO-800, HEMO-900, HEMO-1000, and HEMO-1100 were 93.3%, 96.9%, 97.2%, and 91.6%, respectively. The HEMO-800 synthesized at 800 °C exhibited inferior catalytic performance due to the lower calcination temperature, which led to the incomplete formation of a pure spinel high-entropy structure. In contrast, HEMO-900 demonstrated a sulfur removal of after 8 h of reaction. However, HEMO-1100 displayed lower sulfur conversion efficiency and failed to achieve deep desulfurization within 8 h. This can be attributed to the sintering and agglomeration of the catalyst particles at 1100 °C, resulting in reduced specific surface area and a decrease in active sites, thereby partially inhibiting catalytic activity. Considering both activity and structural factors, the optimal synthesis temperature is determined to be 900 °C. It is noteworthy that during the ODS process, the ODS rate initially starts slowly, then increases, and eventually slows down again. Such a change in the ODS rate can be explained as follows: In the ODS process, the HEMO-900 catalyst initially adsorbs sulfides and oxygen molecules, activating them for catalytic oxidation. Due to varying adsorption capacities, substrate molecule concentration on the catalyst surface is initially low, resulting in a slow reaction rate. Subsequently, HEMO-900 activates oxygen molecules, forming superoxide radicals as active intermediates, catalyzing sulfide oxidation. However, this stage requires time, resulting in low concentrations of active intermediates and a slow reaction rate. Additionally, oxygen molecules need to diffuse to catalytic active sites, also contributing to the initial low reaction rate. As the reaction progresses, superoxide radical concentration increases, enhancing the ODS rate. Toward the end of the ODS reaction, despite a high superoxide radical concentration, decreased sulfide concentration and adsorbed oxide products on the catalyst surface lead to a decline in the reaction rate. To assess the effect of temperature on the desulfurization performance, ODS experiments with oxygen as the oxidant were conducted at different reaction temperatures. The experimental results are presented in Fig. 7(b). At a reaction temperature of 110 °C, the catalyst exhibited a low conversion rate of only 16.8% for DBT after 8 h of reaction. This finding underscores the significant influence of reaction temperature on the catalyst's performance, with lower temperatures being unfavorable for the catalytic oxidation process. Upon increasing the temperature to 115 °C, with the existence of a notable improvement in the sulfur conversion rate was achieved, reaching 73.7% after 8 h of reaction. Further increasing the reaction temperature to 120 °C, a sulfur removal of 96.9% after 8 h of reaction was gained. Considering both the sulfur conversion efficiency and costs in industrial catalysis, a reaction temperature of 120 °C was selected as the optimal choice for the HEMO-900 catalyst. To evaluate the activity of HEMO-900 towards various sulfur-containing compounds found in real refinery fuel oils, the ODS performance of the catalyst towards 4,6-DMDBT and 4-MDBT was further investigated. The results, as depicted in Fig. 7(c), revealed that HEMO-900 achieved sulfur conversion rates of 100% for both 4,6-DMDBT and 4-MDBT while maintaining a conversion rate of 96.9% for DBT after 8 h of reaction. These findings demonstrate the excellent ODS performance of HEMO-900 towards different sulfur compounds. Furthermore, the catalytic activity exhibited the following trend in terms of decreasing sulfur conversion rates: 4,6-DMDBT > DBT > 4-MDBT. This difference in sulfur removals can be attributed to the electron densities of the sulfur atoms and the steric hindrance effect. Among these three sulfides, 4,6-DMDBT possesses the highest electron cloud density of sulfur atoms (5.760) [56]. Consequently, HEMO-900 demonstrates the highest ODS performance to 4,6-DMDBT. Although the electron cloud density of sulfur atoms in 4-MDBT (5.759) is higher than that in DBT (5.7658) [56], the presence of a side-chain methyl group in 4-MDBT introduces a steric hindrance effect, leading to a slightly lower removal performance of HEMO-900 for 4-MDBT compared to DBT. In addition, to emulate the coexistence of different aromatic sulfides in real diesel oil, a model oil was formulated with a sulfide concentration of approximately 0.06% by dissolving DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT in dodecane. The ODS efficiency of HEMO-900 on this model oil was examined, and the outcomes are depicted in Fig. S13. It can be seen from the result that after an 8 h reaction, HEMO-900 successfully reduced the sulfide concentration in the model oil from 0.05865% to 0.00086%, showcasing remarkable desulfurization capabilities even in the presence of multiple sulfides. In the realm of industrial production, the initial sulfur contents of various oil feedstocks may differ. Thus, the desulfurization activities of the HEMO-900 catalyst over model oils with varying initial sulfur contents were investigated in Fig. 7(d). Under identical reaction conditions, the catalyst demonstrated consistent and stable catalytic activity to oils with sulfur contents of 0.02%, 0.03%, and 0.04%. After 8 h of reaction, all the sulfur removals of DBT remained above 95%, indicating the capability for achieving deep desulfurization. These experimental findings indicate that the sulfur contents had no impact on the catalytic activity of the HEMO-900 catalyst. Consequently, it can effectively accommodate oil feedstocks with varying sulfur contents. Moreover, we investigated the effect of oxygen flow rate on the ODS performance of HEMO-900, as illustrated in Fig. 7(e). The results reveal a significant enhancement in ODS performance as the oxygen flow rate increased from 100 to 150 mL min−1, reaching 96.9% from an initial value of 91.7% after an reaction. This improvement is attributed to the elevated oxygen flow rate, inducing an increased presence of dissolved oxygen in the fuel oil phase and thereby amplifying the generation of active intermediates before reaching dissolution equilibrium. However, with a further increase in the oxygen flow rate from 150 to 200 mL min−1, the subsequent augmentation in ODS performance became less pronounced. Consequently, after careful consideration, 150 mL min−1 was selected as the optimized oxygen flow rate. To explore the catalytic activity sites of HEMO-900, a series of control samples were synthesized including single metal oxide catalysts (CoO x , FeO x , NiO x , CrO x , and MnO x ), a bimetallic metal oxide (CoCrO x ), and a trimetallic metal oxide (FeMnNiO x ) under the same procedures of HEMO-900. Furthermore, the ODS performances of all these catalysts were assessed under optimized conditions, and the findings are illustrated in Fig. 7(f). Notably, the CoO x and CrO x catalysts exhibited superior ODS performance, achieving desulfurization rates of 66.6% and 70.7%, respectively. In contrast, FeO x , NiO x , and MnO x catalysts demonstrated comparatively lower ODS performance. These results suggest that within HEMO-900, Co and Cr may function as catalytic active centers, while Fe, Ni, and Mn contribute to the formation of a high-entropy structure. Further comparison between the catalytic activities of CoCrO x binary metal oxide catalyst and FeMnNiO x ternary catalyst indicates that the ODS activity of CoCrO x surpasses that of FeMnNiO x , providing additional evidence that Co and Cr serve as the catalytic active sites. To highlight the effect of forming a high-entropy structure on catalytic performance, all five single metal oxides were physically grounded and mixed for ODS. However, the resulting desulfurization rate was only 83.8%, considerably lower than HEMO-900’s impressive desulfurization rate of 96.9%. This underscores the significant improvement in catalytic performance achieved through the formation of a high-entropy structure. The final products of the ODS reaction were analyzed using GC-MS analysis. Fig. 8 presents the results obtained from GC-MS characterization. In the mass spectrum analysis, a peak at the retention time of 7.01 min corresponds to the DBT present in the model oil phase. However, no significant DBT peak was observed in either the catalyst phase or the oil phase after the reaction. This observation indicates the removal of DBT in the oil through the ODS process. Furthermore, a peak was detected at a retention time of 11.49 min in the catalyst phase after the reaction, which is assigned to the ODS product, sulfone (DBTO2). In addition, beside the DBTO2 peak, no additional peak was detected in the GC-MS result of the catalyst phase and oil phase after the ODS reaction. These findings provide evidence that during the ODS process, DBT can be entirely transformed into DBTO2. In industrial applications, the recovery and recyclability of catalysts play a crucial role in determining operational and maintenance costs. Hence, the recovery and reusability performance of the catalyst was further evaluated. In recent years, magnetic separation technology has emerged as a promising and efficient technique for catalyst separation and recovery, which simplifies the catalyst recovery process, reduces operational costs, and enables the utilization of powdered catalysts. The successful application of this technology relies on the catalyst possessing favorable magnetic properties, allowing easy magnetization and demagnetization. To assess the magnetic properties of the synthesized HEMO-900 catalyst, a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) was employed, and the magnetic hysteresis loop of the samples is depicted in Fig. 9 . The saturation magnetization of the samples was determined to be 12.2 emu g−1 (Fig. 9(a)), indicating superparamagnetic behavior. This behavior enables the catalyst to be uniformly dispersed in the oil phase during the reaction and subsequently be swiftly separated and recovered by applying an external magnetic field. The insert in Fig. 9(a) demonstrates the effective dispersion of the HEMO-900 catalyst in the oil phase during the ODS process, facilitating efficient interaction with substrate molecules and enhancing the ODS performance. Subsequently, owing to its exceptional magnetic properties, the catalyst can be rapidly separated for recovery using an external magnetic field. This magnetic separation and recovery approach significantly enhances the recovery efficiency and reusability of the catalyst, thereby reducing catalyst loss and replacement costs while minimizing overall operational and maintenance expenses. Moreover, cycling experiments were conducted to assess the catalyst's recyclability in Fig. 9(b). The result demonstrates that the HEMO-900 catalyst maintained a remarkable sulfur removal efficiency of 91.1% even in the 5th cycle. This exceptional recyclability can be attributed to the stability of the high-entropy structure and the effective dispersion of elements of HEMO-900. The finding not only highlights the efficient recovery capability of HEMO-900 but also indicates its promising potential for industrial applications. ESR spectroscopy with dimethylpyridine nitrogen oxide (DMPO) as a radical scavenger was employed to investigate the generation of free radicals during the reaction and gain insights into the reaction mechanism. Fig. 10 presents the obtained results. The absence of an ESR signal in the absence of a catalyst indicates that molecular oxygen is not activated for catalytic oxidation desulfurization without a catalyst. However, upon the addition of the HEMO-900 catalyst, a strong signal peak emerges, which can be attributed to the presence of superoxide radicals based on comparison. This suggests that HEMO-900 initially activates the O2 molecule, leading to the formation of superoxide radicals that exhibit high catalytic oxidation activity. These superoxide radicals subsequently facilitate the oxidation of DBT to sulfones, thereby achieving effective oxidative desulfurization. To investigate the stability of the HEMO-900 catalyst after the reaction, XRD characterization was performed. The XRD pattern of the HEMO-900 catalysts before and after the reaction were compared in Fig. S14. It was observed that additional peaks appeared in the post-reaction HEMO-900 catalyst, which were identified as diffraction peaks corresponding to DBTO2. Notably, the characteristic peaks of HEMO-900 remained unchanged during the reaction, indicating the excellent stability of the catalyst throughout the reaction process. These results suggest that the catalyst maintains its structural integrity and stability, highlighting its stability in the ODS process. Moreover, to further clarify the stability of HEMO-900, the post-reaction HEMO-900 catalyst was washed with ethanol and characterized by XRD analysis. As depicted in Fig. S15, there is virtually no alteration in HEMO-900 before and after the reaction, providing additional evidence of its exceptional stability. Further characterization of the post-reaction HEMO-900 using TEM and EDS mapping in Fig. S16 indicates that all elements in the catalyst remain uniformly dispersed after the reaction, and its morphology exhibits no significant changes compared to the pre-reaction HEMO-900. The analysis confirms the outstanding stability of HEMO-900. The potential application of the HEMO-900 catalyst in industrial production and its catalytic activity on real diesel samples were further evaluated. A real diesel sample with a measured total sulfur content of 0.02369% (determined by an ultraviolet fluorescence sulfur analyzer at a cracking chamber temperature of 950 °C) was chosen for the experiment. After an 8-h reaction with HEMO-900 as the catalyst and oxygen as the oxidant, along with a subsequent extraction treatment, the sulfur content in the diesel was reduced to 0.00251%, corresponding to a desulfurization efficiency of approximately 89.4%. Upon comparing the results with those obtained from the treatment of model oil, it was observed that HEMO-900 exhibited lower performance in the catalytic oxidation desulfurization of real diesel. This disparity can be attributed to several factors. Firstly, real diesel comprises a diverse range of sulfur-containing compounds as substrates and contains a significant number of hydrocarbons and olefins, creating a complex reaction environment. Secondly, the diesel sample may contain impurities such as organic acids and nitrogen-containing compounds, which compete with sulfur-containing substrates for adsorption on the active sites of HEMO-900. This competition leads to the deactivation of the active sites and subsequently reduces the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, a high-entropy metal oxide catalyst, CoCrFeMnNiO x (HEMO-900), was synthesized using a mechanical ball milling-assisted calcination method. The synthesis process involved utilizing metal salts as precursors and adhering to the Hume-Rothery rules and principles of high-entropy solid solution phase formation. Characterization techniques confirmed the successful formation of a pure single-phase spinel solid solution. A comparison of XRD patterns between samples synthesized via different methods demonstrated that mechanical ball milling-assisted synthesis could lower the temperature required for the formation of the high-entropy structure. EDS-mapping characterization and XRD analysis conducted on samples synthesized at different temperatures further revealed the excellent structural stability of the HEMO-900 material. Furthermore, the HEMO-900 was employed as a catalyst for ODS with oxygen as the oxidant. The HEMO-900 exhibited remarkable ODS performance and achieved deep desulfurization in various oil samples under optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, the study highlighted the advantageous magnetic properties, excellent cyclic regeneration performance, and capability for by-product separation and recovery of HEMO-900. The magnetic property not only ensures efficient separation performance but also can provide convenience for the separation of ODS by-products, which is a type of high-value-added product. coredata.dc:description: High-entropy metal oxide catalysts have demonstrated exceptional performance in activating oxygen for catalytic oxidation reactions. However, ensuring their ease of cyclic usage is crucial to broadening their applications. To address this challenge, a magnetic and recyclable high-entropy metal oxide catalyst is designed and its potential in catalytic oxidative desulfurization of fuel oils with oxygen as the oxidant is also investigated. Through a mechanochemical-assisted calcination method, the magnetic high-entropy metal oxide catalyst (HEMO-900) is successfully synthesized, and the structure of the HEMO-900 catalyst is comprehensively characterized. In addition, it is found that the high-entropy structure facilitates charge modulation of the active components, thereby enhancing the oxygen activation performance. The HEMO-900 catalyst exhibits exceptional oxygen activation ability and catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance, and 96.9% of sulfur removal is achieved under optimal conditions. In addition, it achieves profound desulfurization of various fuel samples by efficiently oxidizing and eliminating diverse aromatic sulfur compounds. Additionally, the catalyst demonstrates outstanding magnetically recyclable properties, enabling rapid separation and recovery from the fuel oil phase through the application of an external magnetic field, making the HEMO-900 catalyst maintained a remarkable sulfur removal efficiency of 91.1% even in the 5th cycle. Therefore, this magnetically recyclable HEMO-900 catalyst possesses significantly promising research and application prospects in the field of catalytic oxidative desulfurization of fuel oils with oxygen as the oxidant, as well as some other heterogeneous catalysis.
